abstract.para: After the upgrade, you need to perform some additional tasks. The following chapter guides you through these steps.

sect1.title: Check for old packages
sect1.para: Check for orphaned and unneeded packages. Orphaned packages are no longer available in any of the configured package repositories. The can no longer get updated and become unsupported. Unneeded packages were installed as dependencies of packages that have been removed in the meantime. They are no longer needed and should be removed, too.

sect1.title: Review your configuration files
sect1.para: Check for any *.rpmnew and *.rpmsave files. When an upgrade includes changes to a default configuration file that has been altered after package installation, instead of overwriting the file, one of these file types is created. While *.rpmnew contains the new default configuration and leaves your altered file untouched, *.rpmsave is a copy of your altered configuration that has been replaced by the new default file.
If you find any of these files, examine their content and merge desirable changes. You do not need to search the whole file system but only the /etc directory. Use the following command:

sect1.title: Enable the Python 3 module
sect1.para: &productname; 15 uses Python 3.6 by default. Python 3.9 was added in &productnameshort; 15 SP3 as a more recent alternative. This version is no longer supported as of &productnameshort; 15 SP4. Instead, recent Python versions with important updates and security fixes are available through the Python 3 module.

Alternatively, you can return to the default Python version by removing 3.9 with zypper remove -u python39.

sect1.title: Reformat XFS v4 devices
sect1.para: &productname; supports the on-disk format (v5) of the XFS file system. The main advantages of this format are automatic checksums of all XFS metadata, file type support, and support for a larger number of access control lists for a file.

sect1.title: Upgrading from &productname; 11 SP4
sect1.para: Depending on the &sle; version you upgrade from, you need to perform different additional tasks. The following sections provide an overview of version-specific upgrade steps.

sect2.title: Reconfigure the keyboard layout
sect2.para: If you are experiencing an incorrect keyboard layout on your virtual consoles, run yast keyboard to reconfigure the keyboard layout. Alternatively, you can set the desired KEYMAP option in the configuration file /etc/vconsole.conf directly, for example KEYMAP=us.

sect2.title: Add missing system users and groups
sect2.para: If the Name Service Switch (NSS) configuration file /etc/nsswitch.conf uses additional databases such as LDAP for user and group resolution, and these databases are unavailable during the upgrade, the post installation script of the systemd package is unable to create requird system users.

If you keep seeing warning messages in the journal when systemd-tmpfiles-setup.service starts, update the configuration files in /usr/lib/tmpfiles.d/. Remove any duplicate entries and replace references to the old directory /var/run with the new location /run.
